short_description: The crown jewel of Saudi cuisine, featuring fragrant spiced rice topped with tender meat, garnished with fried nuts and raisins. This aromatic one-pot feast is the heart of every Saudi gathering and celebration.
steps: Season chicken or lamb with kabsa spice and salt, set aside.
Heat oil in a large pot and brown the meat on all sides.
Remove meat and sauté onions until golden.
Add garlic, chopped tomatoes, and tomato paste. Cook for 5 minutes.
Return meat to pot with whole spices and dried limes.
Add enough water to cover meat, simmer until tender (45-60 minutes).
Remove meat and strain broth, measure out 4 cups for rice.
Wash rice and add to the broth, cook until fluffy.
Fry almonds and raisins in butter until golden.
Serve rice on a large platter, top with meat and garnish with nuts and raisins.
cooking_tips: Dried limes (loomi) add a unique tangy flavor - pierce them before adding.
The kabsa spice mix typically includes cumin, coriander, cloves, cardamom, and pepper.
Traditionally served on a large communal platter.
nutrition_benefits: A complete meal providing protein from meat, complex carbohydrates from rice, and healthy fats from nuts. The spices aid digestion and have anti-inflammatory properties.

short_description: A comforting Saudi porridge made from crushed wheat cooked slowly with meat until creamy and rich. This traditional dish is especially popular during Ramadan and cold winter months.
steps: Soak the crushed wheat in water for 1 hour, then drain.
Cook meat in broth until tender, about 1 hour.
Remove meat, shred it, and reserve the broth.
Sauté onion and garlic in ghee until golden.
Add tomatoes and spices, cook for 5 minutes.
Add the soaked wheat and reserved broth.
Simmer on low heat, stirring frequently, for 1-1.5 hours.
The dish is ready when wheat is creamy and porridge-like.
Stir in the shredded meat.
Serve hot, drizzled with extra ghee and optionally yogurt.
cooking_tips: Constant stirring prevents sticking and ensures creamy texture.
The longer it cooks, the creamier it becomes.
Some prefer it smooth, others like a bit of texture.
nutrition_benefits: Crushed wheat is high in fiber and provides sustained energy. The slow-cooked meat is easy to digest. A warming, nutritious meal perfect for recovery or during fasting.

short_description: A crispy stuffed pancake filled with spiced meat, eggs, and vegetables. This popular street food is folded into a perfect square and pan-fried until golden and flaky.
steps: Cook ground meat with diced onion and spices until browned.
Let the meat mixture cool slightly.
Beat eggs and mix with cooked meat, chopped green onions, and chilies.
Lay out spring roll wrappers, overlapping two slightly.
Place filling in the center of each wrapper.
Fold the edges to create a square parcel.
Heat oil in a flat pan over medium heat.
Fry each mutabbaq until golden and crispy on both sides.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with pickled vegetables or chili sauce.
cooking_tips: Keep wrappers covered with a damp cloth to prevent drying.
Don't overfill or the parcels will burst while frying.
Traditional versions use a hand-stretched dough.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein from meat and eggs. The crispy exterior comes from pan-frying rather than deep-frying, making it lighter than other fried snacks.

short_description: A creamy Saudi comfort food from the Hijaz region, featuring tender chicken atop silky rice cooked in milk and chicken broth. Often called Saudi risotto for its luxurious texture.
steps: Boil chicken with cardamom and salt until fully cooked.
Remove chicken, strain and reserve the broth.
Wash rice thoroughly until water runs clear.
Toast rice briefly in butter until slightly golden.
Add chicken broth and crushed mastic gum.
Simmer until rice absorbs most of the liquid.
Gradually add warm milk, stirring gently.
Continue cooking until rice is creamy and soft.
Grill or roast the boiled chicken until skin is crispy.
Serve creamy rice with chicken pieces on top.
cooking_tips: Egyptian rice gives the best creamy texture, but short-grain rice works too.
Mastic gum adds a unique subtle pine flavor - use sparingly.
Keep adding warm liquid if rice seems too thick.
nutrition_benefits: A calcium-rich dish thanks to the milk. Chicken provides lean protein while the rice offers energy-sustaining carbohydrates.

short_description: A beloved Arabian porridge of slow-cooked wheat and meat, beaten to a smooth, comforting consistency. This ancient dish is especially cherished during Ramadan and is known for being easy to digest.
steps: Soak wheat overnight in plenty of water.
Drain wheat and place in a large pot with meat.
Add water and salt, bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 3-4 hours, stirring occasionally.
When meat is falling apart and wheat is very soft, beat vigorously.
Traditionally beaten with a wooden paddle until smooth.
Modern method: blend partially for similar texture.
Continue cooking until thick and porridge-like.
Serve in bowls with melted ghee and cinnamon on top.
Traditionally eaten with spoons or scooped with bread.
cooking_tips: The longer you cook and beat, the smoother the texture.
Don't skip the soaking - it's essential for proper texture.
Some add sugar on top instead of cinnamon.
nutrition_benefits: Whole wheat provides fiber and B vitamins. The slow-cooking breaks down proteins for easy digestion, making it ideal for breaking fasts. Ghee adds healthy saturated fats.

short_description: A traditional Saudi dish featuring layers of bread soaked in rich lamb broth, topped with tender meat and a tangy tomato sauce. A hearty comfort food enjoyed throughout the Kingdom.
steps: Boil lamb with onion, garlic, and dried limes until very tender.
Remove lamb and reserve the rich broth.
Shred the meat into large pieces.
Make sauce by sautéing tomatoes with tomato paste and spices.
Toast bread until slightly crispy.
Layer bread pieces in a deep serving dish.
Ladle hot broth over bread to soak it.
Top with shredded lamb.
Drizzle with tomato sauce.
Serve immediately while bread is still warm.
cooking_tips: The bread should absorb the broth but not become mushy.
Use thin Arabic bread for best results.
Dried limes add a distinctive tangy flavor to the broth.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein from lamb. The slow-cooked broth is rich in collagen. A warming, filling meal.

short_description: Aromatic rice and meat cooked together with a unique smoky flavor, traditionally prepared in an underground clay oven. The rice absorbs the rich meat juices and spices.
steps: Marinate meat with hawaij spice, salt, and some ghee.
Boil meat with whole spices until almost tender.
Reserve the flavorful broth for cooking rice.
Soak rice for 30 minutes, then drain.
Fry onions until deeply caramelized.
Add rice to the broth and cook until fluffy.
For smoking, place hot charcoal in a small bowl.
Drizzle ghee on charcoal and cover quickly to trap smoke.
Let the dish absorb the smoky flavor for 10 minutes.
Serve rice on a platter with meat on top.
cooking_tips: The smoking step is essential for authentic flavor.
Traditional mandi is cooked underground with hot coals.
Home version uses the charcoal smoking technique.
nutrition_benefits: Complete meal with protein from meat and carbs from rice. Aromatic spices aid digestion. Rich in B vitamins and iron.

short_description: Buried rice dish where meat is cooked covered with rice, allowing all the flavors to meld together. The name means 'buried' referring to the cooking technique.
steps: Season chicken with bezar spice and salt.
Brown chicken in oil on all sides.
Add sliced onions and cook until soft.
Add tomatoes and whole spices.
Cover with water and simmer until chicken is nearly done.
Remove chicken and measure out broth for rice.
Place chicken back in pot.
Cover with washed rice and add measured broth.
Cook covered until rice is fluffy and liquid absorbed.
Garnish with fried almonds and raisins.
cooking_tips: Don't stir once rice is added.
The bottom of the pot may get a crispy layer - this is prized.
Let rest before serving for best texture.
nutrition_benefits: Lean protein from chicken. Complex carbs from basmati rice. Nuts add healthy fats and minerals.

short_description: Crispy triangular pastries filled with spiced meat or vegetables. These golden fried snacks are especially popular during Ramadan iftar gatherings.
steps: Cook ground beef with diced onion and spices.
Add chopped parsley, cool the filling.
Cut each wrapper into three long strips.
Place a spoonful of filling at the bottom corner.
Fold into a triangle shape, continue folding.
Seal the edge with flour paste.
Deep fry in batches until golden brown.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with chili sauce or tamarind dip.
cooking_tips: Keep unused wrappers covered to prevent drying.
Don't overfill or they will burst.
Fry at medium heat for even cooking.
nutrition_benefits: Protein from meat filling. A satisfying snack best enjoyed in moderation. Perfect for breaking the fast.

short_description: A hearty Saudi stew with hand-torn dough pieces cooked with meat and vegetables. This rustic dish is especially popular in the Najd region.
steps: Make simple dough with flour, salt, and water, rest 30 minutes.
Brown meat in ghee with onion.
Add tomatoes and spices, cook briefly.
Add water and bring to boil.
Add harder vegetables first (potatoes, carrots).
Roll dough very thin, tear into rough pieces.
Add dough pieces to the simmering stew.
Add remaining vegetables.
Cover and cook until dough is soft.
Serve in deep bowls with plenty of broth.
cooking_tips: The dough pieces should be very thin.
Don't stir too much after adding dough.
The stew should be thick and hearty.
nutrition_benefits: Protein from meat. Vegetables provide vitamins and fiber. A warming, complete meal.

short_description: A beloved Arabian dish of thin bread pieces soaked in rich lamb and vegetable stew. This ancient dish is said to have been a favorite of Prophet Muhammad.
steps: Brown lamb pieces in oil.
Add onions and garlic, cook until soft.
Add tomatoes and spices.
Cover with water and simmer until meat is tender.
Add potatoes and cook for 15 minutes.
Add zucchini and cook until all vegetables are done.
Tear bread into large pieces.
Arrange bread in serving dish.
Ladle stew over bread.
Garnish with fresh cilantro.
cooking_tips: Use thin bread that absorbs liquid well.
The bread should be soft but not dissolved.
Serve immediately for best texture.
nutrition_benefits: High protein from lamb. Rich in vitamins from vegetables. Easy to digest and nourishing.

short_description: A sweet Saudi dessert made from dates, bread, and cream, mashed together into a rich, satisfying treat. Popular in the southern regions of Saudi Arabia.
steps: Toast bread lightly and crumble it.
Mash dates until smooth.
Melt ghee in a large pan.
Add crumbled bread and dates.
Mix well and cook briefly.
Add cream and mix until combined.
Drizzle with honey.
Sprinkle with black seeds.
Serve warm in a communal dish.
cooking_tips: Use soft dates for easier mashing.
The texture should be thick but not dry.
Best served warm for breakfast.
nutrition_benefits: Dates provide natural sugars and fiber. Quick energy source. Black seeds have immune-boosting properties.

short_description: A spicy-sweet red pepper and walnut dip with pomegranate molasses. This rich spread is perfect as a mezze or with grilled meats.
steps: Roast peppers until charred, peel and seed.
Toast walnuts lightly.
Blend roasted peppers with walnuts and garlic.
Add breadcrumbs and pomegranate molasses.
Stream in olive oil while blending.
Season with cumin, chili, and salt.
Chill for 30 minutes for flavors to meld.
Drizzle with olive oil before serving.
Serve with warm pita bread.
cooking_tips: Roasting peppers adds smoky depth.
Adjust chili to your heat preference.
Gets better after resting overnight.
nutrition_benefits: Walnuts provide omega-3 fatty acids. Red peppers are rich in vitamin C. Heart-healthy fats from olive oil.

short_description: Crispy shredded phyllo pastry layered with sweet cheese and soaked in rose-scented sugar syrup. This beloved Middle Eastern dessert is especially popular during Ramadan.
steps: If using akkawi cheese, soak in water to remove salt.
Make sugar syrup by boiling sugar and water, add lemon and rose water.
Melt butter and mix with shredded kunafa dough.
Press half the dough into a round baking pan.
Add cheese layer evenly.
Top with remaining dough, press down.
Bake at 180°C (350°F) for 40 minutes until golden.
Immediately pour cold syrup over hot kunafa.
Flip onto serving plate.
Garnish with crushed pistachios.
cooking_tips: The dough must be completely coated with butter.
Pour cold syrup on hot kunafa for best absorption.
Serve immediately for the crispiest texture.
nutrition_benefits: Cheese provides calcium and protein. A celebratory treat best enjoyed in moderation. Rose water has calming properties.
